content.content: pflegen (weak, third-person singular present pflegt, past tense pflegte, past participle gepflegt, auxiliary haben)
From Middle High German phlëgen, from Old High German plëgan, from Proto-West Germanic *plehan.

content: Providing care or service for someone/something. [weak verb]
to nurse; to care for someone in poor health

content.content: to nurse someone back to health

content: to take care of, to tend to, to maintain

content.content: to take care of one's appearance

content: To improve or care for something in an intellectual sense. [weak or strong verb]
to cultivate; to foster; to nurture; to maintain

content.content: to socialize regularly (literally, “to regularly engage in gregariousness”)

content: (with “zu” followed by an infinitive verb) to perform habitually; to be accustomed (to doing something); to be in the habit (of doing something)

content.content: Fuchs m (strong, genitive Fuchses, plural Füchse, diminutive Füchslein n or Füchschen n, feminine Füchsin)

From Middle High German vuhs, from Old High German fuhs, from Proto-West Germanic *fuhs, from Proto-Germanic *fuhsaz, from Proto-Indo-European *púḱsos (“the tailed one”), from *puḱ- (“tail”). Cognate with English fox, Sanskrit पुच्छ (púccha).
Fuchs, du hast die Gans gestohlen. Gib sie wieder her!
Er ist ein ganz schöner Fuchs.
He is a really handsome fox.
Unser Paul ist ja ein kleiner Fuchs.
Our Paul is a little redhead.

content: In Doppelkopf, the ace of diamonds, which earns a side of players an extra point if they win it from the other side

content.content: Ich hatte nur vier Trümpfe und darunter beide Füchse.
I had only four trumps and among them were both aces of diamonds.

content: A form of sunscald on hops.

content.content: Herz n (weak, genitive Herzens or (very rare) Herzes, plural Herzen, diminutive Herzchen n or Herzlein n or ((also) Ruhrpöttisch) Herzken n)

From Middle High German herze, from Old High German herza, from Proto-West Germanic *hertā, from Proto-Germanic *hertô (“heart”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱḗr (“heart”).
Cognate with Dutch hart, English heart, Danish hjerte, Gothic 𐌷𐌰𐌹𐍂𐍄𐍉 (hairtō).
Fahrer m (strong, genitive Fahrers, plural Fahrer, feminine Fahrerin)

From Middle High German von (“from”), from Old High German fon, fona (“from”), from Proto-Germanic *afanē, *fanē, *funē (“from”), compound of *afa (from Proto-Indo-European *h₂epó (“from, off”)) + *ana (from Proto-Indo-European *h₂en- (“on”)). Cognate with Old Saxon fana, fan (“from”), Dutch van (“from; of”), Old Frisian fon (“from”).
Ich fahre von Köln nach Hamburg.
I'm travelling from Cologne to Hamburg.
Ich hab’s von meiner Schwester gehört.
I heard it from my sister.

content: of, belonging to (often replacing genitive; see usage note below)

content.content: das Auto meines Vaters = das Auto von meinem Vater
my father’s car / the car of my father
Das Hotel wird von der Firma bezahlt.
The hotel is paid for by the company.
Er hat von seiner Jugend erzählt.
Von dem Nomine Substantivo, oder dem Hauptworte.
About the substantive noun, or the [alternative term]. (headline)
Von welchem Geld soll ich als Arbeitsloser in Urlaub fahren?
Being unemployed, on what money should I go on holidays?
Man kann nicht nur von Luft und Liebe leben.
You can’t live on air and love alone. (proverb)

From Middle High German base, from Old High German basa, from Proto-Germanic *baswǭ (“father's sister; paternal aunt”). Compare Saterland Frisian Bääsje (“grandmother”), Dutch baas (“master; boss”). More at boss.
19th c., backformation from Basen, plural of Basis, from Latin basis, from Ancient Greek βάσις (básis).

content: base (compound that will neutralize an acid)
